subject: Design : HMC lock Management
commitMessage:
Design : HMC lock Management

This commit describes the BMC interface for HMC lock management

Signed-off-by: Manojkiran Eda <manojkiran.eda@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Idd99ce31d7748d7e6649f35df7ad5279678739b0

comments.message:
Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Made comments on https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/meta-ibm/+/25232 which apply here. I feel this needs a little work to be consumable by the community (non-IBMers). Some IBM lingo snuck in when it is not needed. Why the same commit to both docs/ and meta-ibm/ ?

Thanks for the review comments Gunnar, I remember - there was a discuss with brad to decide on which repo we should place these ibm specific docs. Thats why i have pushed into meta-ibm/docs as well.

But i feel that openbmc/docs is the best place to put them.I have made the changes as per your review comments at https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/#/c/openbmc/meta-ibm/+/25232/ , please review the new patch set.

Patch Set 24:

@Brad, since this is now IBM-specific I'll let you take it from here.

Abandoned

No one seemed to have interest in reviewing this patch, and i am sure that no one in the community is really looking for this feature. Abandoning this as i am tired of seeing this patch in my list.

There can be multiple lock request.
Each lock request requires
=> LockType
=> Resource ID
=> [{lock_level,length},.....]
Move the segmentflag as the 4th item. And move the resourceId at the last.
Add segment flags in the example
It is a spelling mistake ... resource.
I don't understand why do we need the D-bus mapping for all the resources.
One-liner of what this API does? Please define the description for all the API in the document.
the session ID is not required. the webserver can automatically get the session id from the request.

Should It be GetLockList(): HMC can ask the list of locks owned by the given session.
For HMC to get the lock table
1/ Get all the sessions via GET request on Session Service
2/ GetLockList for a session or list of sessions.
Can you also define in one-liner what the API does?
Can we have this resource path align with the linux device tree path which both currently BMC / HOST going to follow.
yes sivas, we can have ..this would be the generic way of solving the lock management problem
Leave one space prior to starting parentheses.

- Express the plural of HMC as HMCs.  HMC's appears to be possessive.

Fix throughout file.

- *collisions

thought *of

or...

Delete "that were thought of".  We can assume that somebody thought of it without being told here.
Your first comma needs a space following it.

- Don't use "below" as an adjective.
- No space prior to colon.

in the following links:
- Every lock request issued by the HMC should be assigned a unique RequestID.
- Multiple write locks on the same resource are prohibited.
Should this go under designs/management-console like https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/23484/4 ?

Please add a line saying why the lock mechanism is needed ? Say that its for getting the mutual exclusion/synchronization  on the operations performed by HMC on the CEC, when there are more than one HMC managing the CEC

As per Gunnars comments, i have modified the para.

I think this is line is enough right  ?  "Since multiple HMCs can
control the same system, a locking mechanism is needed."
There is a separate zHMC which manages the z systems. That HMC can not manage the power servers. Please remove the System Z reference here.
I thought of giving a reference for the link, and missed the syntax. Removed it as it is unnecessary.
GetLockList is finalized, So modified it.

URI should be /ibm/v1...
locktype:<read/write> ---> can be an enum
lockflags:<lock/dontlock> --->can be an enum
segmentlength ---> can be an integer.
these are not seen as bullets in the markdown editor. Please modify
I think giving example for locking a resource would be good
As we are mentioning in other design documents, please put the exact sample outputs here.

URI should be /ibm/v1/..
Just a thought ... can this be a DELETE request?

It is Similar to removing an entry from the internal data structure(lock table).

If we are maintaining a DBUS object for every lock that is obtained then, it is equivalent to DELETE, but in this case we dont need to maintain DBUS objects for every lock right ?
this is shown as a smiley in the markdown editor!
All URIs need to be updated to /ibm/v1/..

There was a requirement by HMC saying that :
If there are two HMCs managing the BMC, one HMC should be able to know that a particular resource is locked by which HMC. That is the getLockStatus command. That seems to be missing here.

This requirement is implicitly captured but it is broken into mutliple steps from HMC side.

The HMC would first Query the sessions with a certain privilege on the session service schema and obtain all the session from the session database, and later it can send those session ids, as an input to the GetLockList interface which returns the list of lock records pertaining to that session (which will also have the Client Identifier in it). So this way, the any HMC can know which HMC had locked the resource.
This table looks bad in the Markdown editor. Please check and change as needed.
Isn't this an IBM term? Is there an industry standard term you could use instead?
There is no curl API.. curl command?
REST - As it is an acronym.
Which flag? could you explain it. I believe you meant lock level flag, I guess? correct me if my understand is different. Thank you in advance Manoj.
Ack, My bad..should not have used `This flag` in requirement section.
May be this flag you were mentioning in the "Requirements on Multi Level Locking" Section.
Shall we have this description based on what kind of lock we are releasing it. That helps.

Sivas, The input to the ReleaseLock API is the RequestID (This has the corresponding map with the respective lock resource in HMC & BMC).

So, HMC & BMC know which lock is released in the case of SUCCESS.

In case of Failure, we are giving a description with 
[HMCID:"SampleString",LockType:"write",ResourceID:"String",..]

I think , this should be good enough right ?
It will be helpful if we narrow down the error REST response. That helps us to start automate earlier. Just a suggestion. And helps for more clarity as well.

Sivas, the specific http error code scenarios are not thought yet. These narrow down of error codes are very specific and we can come up with those during the design implementation.

I just wanted this doc to have only design specific requirements and not implementation level details.
Do we need to consider host run time related locks and do we need to have any relationship with PLDM etc..

BMC does not have any knowledge of what lock it has acquired(only HMC will know the lock details).

BMC would merely act as a judge to decide whether it is a legitimate lock or not. There is no need to have any relationship with PLDM at all.
Just an query: If HMC asks for lock of an IO / CEC resources where system is not even powered on , right. How BMC will act at this time in the lock management perspective.?

BMC would just check if the Specified Resource ID(in this case specified IO Adapter of CEC) is already locked with write/read lock and if there is no lock on it, then bmc would return SUCCESS saying , it has locked it(and mark it as locked).

BMC does not care if IO/CEC is powered-on or not. It just checks if there is already a lock to it or not, it should be the HMC's responsibility to check for the state of CEC before taking a lock on it.
Thank you. so BMC no need to worry about PLDM in the lock management perspective. Good.

nit: you already defined HMC above on line 17 and again on line 28.  You could just refer to it as HMC from here on out...

FWIW from a purely separation of concerns point of view the overall focus of this document could be more on the API itself and less on the user of it (HMC).  I'm not asking for changes...just something to keep in mind the next time.

nit: are you referring to the interface between the hmc and the end-user?  I'd suggest leaving this out as it is irrelevant to the interface between the hmc and the bmc, and may potentially add confusion.
nit: there is only one link listed.
"should" indicates that what is being described is recommended but not required.  the correct word here and in the rest of the items is "must"
Yeah, true makes sense..my bad..will modify that.

this is confusing.  How about:

 There must be a provision to unlock all resources under the current resource level.

?

No Brad.

when you say, unlock all resources - that conveys that those set of resources are already locked, and we are trying to unlock all of them - This will be same as calling the releaselock api.

But not lock all - Means that the client(HMC) can send a lock request and explicitly mention to not lock all the resources under a particular segment.

Use Case:

For a particular segment(level), we don't lock anything. But we need to lock the next segment(level).

Example:

Each segment is for one level. For example, the first segment can be CEC (segment size 1, value 1). The second Segment can be a resource under CEC. It can be processor (segment size 1, value 1) or memory (segment size 1, value 2) or partitions (segment size 2, value is the partition id) or a physical IO adapter (segment size 4, value is the adapter's drc index). The third level can be a resource under the second level. For example, if the second level is a partition, the virtual IO adapters for that partition can the the third level (segment size 2, value is the adpapter id). 

If we want to lock all adapters under a partition, The first segment data is 2 bytes data, for that segment we don't lock any resource. But in the next segment is the 4 bytes drc index, we can lock one adapter or lock all adapters. Hope this explains the reason for not lock all resources under current resource level.

there is no dash here.  Is this a continuation of the previous requirement or a different requirement?   I don't understand how this is different from "There should be a provision to lock all resources under current resource level"  Please explain?
both are same, my bad... i will modify accordingly

Which requirement is this an example of?

  There should also be a provision to Lock all resources under current resource level.

or

  There should be a provision to acquire the lock on all the children under a parent resource

?

I wonder if numbering the requirements would help?
What happens if a non-hmc session makes a call to the API?  If that isn't described somewhere it should be.

Brad, these API's would be specific for the hmcuser and would be unauthorised for all the other users. But with that said , these API's would also be accessible for all the Admin users as well (even when they are not HMC Sessions).

This should be covered as a part of Know your client functionality which ratan is proposing, But i will also add a point here to that it would be clear.
What is the session header exactly?  Is there a document I should have read before I read this that explains what an HMC-ID is and where it is stored?
yes brad,I think Know your client should be place where this should be documented.
Based on design point one, this also happens if an hmc account logs out for any reason, right?  I think that is worth documenting.
Sure Brad, i will add another point describing that.
nit: There weren't any requirements listed for this.  If we are going to provide the rationale for some of the endpoints (the requirements) then all of them should be provided.
In https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/23417/7/designs/management-console/file_management.md it is /ibm/v1/host/partitions.. does /ibm/v1/host/ make more sense? Why /ibm/v1/HMC/ here?

So under /ibm/v1/ will be VMInterface, HMC, host ?

VMInterface coming from
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/23420

Is there some capitalization we should follow?
/ibm/v1/host
/ibm/v1/hmc
/ibm/v1/vminterface

Also, I'm not seeing any way for the HMC to introspect the API to figure out what is supported.  e.g. something like the redfish actions property on the locks resource.  Do we need something like that?
Should we should add some restrictions on this parameter?  allowed characters/format?  length?  if it is opaque to the BMC would an integer be easier to deal with?

The idea of segments and flags to realize a multi level lock structure seems unnecessarily complex IMO.  I would guess that anyone that stumbles onto this API description will wonder why a single level lock structure (much like the one described in the fcntl manpages) would not work.  It is worth documenting why that would not work in the alternatives considered section.

Yet another alternative to multi-level locks, if multiple locks do need to be acquired at the same time (which I do not understand why but I will blindly accept that as a requirement for the moment) would be to accept an array argument of resource IDs instead of a single one.  that way the API consumer can manage and own the hierarchical relationship between the resources without any assistance from the BMC and the Segmentflags argument eliminated completely.
I do understand that it is unnecessarily complex IMO, but this is legacy implementation and it is hard to modify it at this point in time.

why not true / false or lock(s) acquired / lock(s) not acquired?  What is the purpose of this token?  Is it related to the resource id somehow?

why is it a list?  of strings?  and not a single bool?

from wikipedia on http 200:

Standard response for successful HTTP requests. The actual response will depend on the request method used. In a GET request, the response will contain an entity corresponding to the requested resource. In a POST request, the response will contain an entity describing or containing the result of the action.

how about just http 200 with a single json True if the lock is acquired, and the data structure below if it is not acquired?

I do understand that generating a unique ID for every transaction and sending to HMC is unnecessary complication, but this is a legacy implementation and it would be very tuff to modify it at this point in time.
This says Failure but below it says "status": "Error"...which one is it?

this is not appropriate: http 400 bad request means:

malformed request syntax, size too large, invalid request message framing, or deceptive request routing

none of which are true in this scenario.

In general http 4xx means "client error".  Is it an error of the client to try to lock a resource that is already locked?  I don't really think so.  Not with the API semantics we have here anyway.

I would suggest you just do something similar to the table in section 7.10 (POST for actions) of the Redfish spec:

https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP0266_1.7.1.pdf

The HyperText Transfer Protocol (HTTP) 400 Bad Request response status code indicates that the server cannot or will not process the request due to something that is perceived to be a client error (e.g., malformed request syntax, invalid request message framing, or deceptive request routing).

When the JSON in the Input, does not adhere to the Spec/Invalid Json, we send 400 BadRequest.

Incase of acquirelock failure due to resource conflict, we return 409 Conflcit.

The HTTP 409 Conflict response status code indicates a request conflict with current state of the server.
this says string but you have an array on line 205.  is it an array of strings?  if it is an array should the method be called ReleaseLocks instead of ReleaseLock ?

The input for the ReleaseLock API would be a Request ID / List of RequestID's.

True, it makes sense to make it as ReleaseLocks instead of ReleaseLock.

What does the HMCID being in the request enable you to do?  Are you going to compare it with the ID in the session table of the calling session?  Why?

if the argument has both the HMCID and the RequestID should it be a json object?  { "RequestID" : "abc123", "HMCID" : "xyz" }

The HMC-ID is an implicit parameter obtained from the session header(It is the client identifier that we need to capture during authentication and store it in session table).

The HMC-ID(is the additional client identifier) would be captured in the Know your client design.

If that is the implicit parameter , we will be just left with RequestID as input right ?

this looks like the old OpenBMC REST API response.  I honestly don't know why I duplicated the http response code in the body.

How about just returning a json true?  What about something from the table on page 47 in the Redfish spec?
Sure brad, i have changed this.

this isn't descriptive enough IMO.  Every single error condition needs to be explicitly stated so that the caller can appropriately handle the error.

What 4xx HTTP responses specifically do you intend to send and in what conditions?
What 5xx HTTP responses specifically do you intend to send and in what conditions?

HTTP 500 makes sense for code bugs (failed asserts, whatever).  you can probably use that for failed kernel calls too (e.g. open/read/write errno).

I don't really think any HTTP 4xx codes make sense here.  For the case where some locks aren't already locked, can you just return HTTP 200 + False + those resource IDs & HMCIDs?  Blank for resource IDs not owned by anyone?
I wonder why the HMC would want to do this in place of just trying to take the lock?  It might be worth explaining to other readers.
Where can I learn more about SessionIDs?  Is this a Redfish thing?  Might want to link the the redfish schema that covers these in the "background" section if that is true.
Aha.  More about sessionIDs here, thanks.  Might still be worth mentioning the relevant Redfish schema as background information.
is the curl command missing here?
This is onyl just the curl response output in-case of Success & failure.
what is the mapping being referred to?  I thought the resource ID was just an opaque handle?

This is an alternative design that we thought of , before implementing the leagacy design.

Where , we try to map the HMC resource -ID with the BMC resources , so that the whole level if resourceID based multi-level locking complexity reduces, but the downside of it is that now when ever HMC adds a new lock(resourceid), the BMC should also update the mappings, which does not seem to a reliable solution to the problem.
I don't understand what drives bmc code changes here...
Suppose, if we have the mapping for resourceids to the BMC resources, then HMC resources drive the bmc code change right ?

did we consider a design where the client (HMC) owns the hierarchy?  e.g. more abstract resources are locked and then more concrete resources are locked?  sequentially?

did we consider an array of locks instead of multi-level locks?

Brad, not sure if it is wrongly conveyed somewhere...even now HMC is the one who controls the resource hierarchy, BMC will have no control over the resources that HMC would manage.

As per the spec, BMC would not understand the resourceid at all, that is totally controlled by HMC.

BMC would merely check the bytes in the resourceids for two requests to tell if the lock request is conflicting or not..but BMC would never know what Virtual resource is actually locked.
why in openbmc_dbus_rest ?  I don't' think that makes sense does it?  openbmc_dbus_rest is for the legacy dbus <-> REST bridging API isn't it?
there isn't anyone from bmcweb on review...lets add someone (probably james)
sure brad, got your point..we have created a new folder <ibm>,and created new header files for this purpose.
what makes a route "custom" exactly?  as opposed to non-custom.
by custom -> i meant that , it is a rest route handle that routes the request to /ibm/v1 rather than the standard /redfish/v1
Did we consider just implementing it in-process?  I doubt we'd ever need an alternative HMC lock implementation and dbus is just going to add latency with no benefit.  James what do you think?
Correct, there will be a lot of overhead. And this is also an discarded alternative design which thought of
I've not seen any justification for a dedicated "HMCD" why not just go directly to the applications that implement the function?

This is also a discarded alternative design.

I have removed these to make sure ..i don't add unnecessary confusions.
doesn't a schema require resources?  I didn't see any resources defined?  And we don't seem to be using the Redfish model at all here...  What aspects of this design are based on the Redfish model?

This is the first approach, which we thought. And i remember ratan talking with the redfish community folks to see if locks can be proposed as new schema..but this is entirely propriety which no one else uses, so discarded this implementation.

I'm confused.  The "alternatives considered" section was above.  So what is this section?  Are there still two designs on the table for consideration?

In the future, when filling out design templates please just include a single proposal.  If there are multiple proposals, find the interested collaborators and figure out which proposal is preferred (with discussion happening somewhere like the mailing list) before filling out the template.
I just wanted to put out all the designs that we thought, to get the intial review comments..but yeah..you are correct should have sent this in the mailing list first.
I have a very slight preference for the first option.  It seems more explicit and easier to validate the arguments.  In the end the information conveyed is the same.
Removed this discarded design completely, so that i dont add unnecessary confusions to the readers
No worries still some small special shown. Overall fine with the changes.
which repositories are impacted?  are any new repositories required?  You mentioned dbus interfaces - will there be new ones added for this?
bmcweb is the only repo, which will be impacted. Having a Dbus interface was proposed as an alternate design(but was discarded, as it includes more overhead).
hopefully we can do this testing without actual hmcs?
Yes Brad, we have already implemented the unit test of all the API's.

A doesn't follow from B.  (Since multiple => locking needed)

We already support many simultaneous accessors via Redfish (among other APIs).  What is special about the HMC?

No patrick, all the redfish resources are tied up with a backend dbus which takes only one request at a time.

The way HMC locks is little different than how a normal redfish resource management work,all the HMC resources are not BMC resources, they are hypervisor resources and the BMC does not know about them.
This needs to be expanded on then in the doc, not just in a comment.  Like I wrote earlier, this sentence doesn't currently make logical sense.

Patrick,

why is lock management implemented in BMC if all the resources are related to hypervisor ? is that you question ?

If it is, Then the answer is its an IBM Hypervisor limitation for now, this was already thought through and IBM agreed on to have it coded inside the BMC itself(and follow legacy due to tight commitments) and this is something that cannot be changed immediately.

This is a NOT the design for a Redfish Interface , and this is the design for Custom REST Interface and is only for IBM Systems.

If what you wrote is true, I'm not sure why this is interesting to document in a public open source repository.  Unfortunately, people tend to use this repository as a "reference" when using it for design direction in the future.  If this isn't a good design, but is a legacy IBM design, I don't see why we want it documented in this repository.  At a minimum, I would suggest we put this under an IBM-specific subdirectory.  (Maybe this whole management-console directory should be ibm/management-console).

Sure Patrick.

ibm/management-console/lock-management.md looks fine for me. I will push it like wise.
What are "parent and child" relationships in this context?  Are we talking about Redfish hierarchy or DBus object paths?  How do we deal with associations?

The HMC is responsible for creating locks with the level(hierarcy) information embedded in it, that information is contained in the ResourceID & Segment Flags.BMC does not know anything about the resource that it is actually locking, but it merely checks for conflicts between two lock requests.

Infact these parent-child hierarchies are neither Redfish hierarchies nor DBus object paths.These are completely owned & maintained by the HMC and is not at all bothered by BMC

Perhaps this should go before you lay out requirements then?

I'm not sure why this is the "hierarchy".  Is this hierarchy currently modeled by the BMC in any way?

This is just a sample resource hierarchy that i have mentioned for the users to get better understanding.

This resource hierarchy is actually maintained with-in the HMC and BMC does not even know about what resources are present in the hierarchy when the lock request comes in, but it merely checks for the conflicts between the incoming request & the existing ones.
Just say BMC does not interpret the resources and their hierarchy. We need not compare this to the redfish resource management etc. This is specific design for intended for HMC requirement only.
If none of the resources managed are owned by the BMC, why is the BMC involved in this at all?  Why do we even have this feature here?
